title: "Trying to Reconnect" Client Issue - Patch 7.1 related
body:
I have an intermittent issue that will pop up randomly no matter where I am in the client. I could be queuing, reading patch notes, or haven't even logged in yet, but I will get the "Trying to Reconnect" screen that will pop up and prevent me from doing anything for 5, 10, or 30+ minutes before it finally goes away. Thinking it was on my end due to a hard drive failure a couple days ago, I went and had a clean install done on a new one. Upon getting everything set up, I load up league only to find that message taunt me every now and again. It's preventing me from playing ranked games since I've already been bugsplatted previously and couldn't connect back in.
After a bunch of attempted troubleshooting on the old hard drive, I think it must be on Riot's end since there really is nothing on this drive. It all started with patch 7.1 being released and is honestly causing quite a headache. I haven't seen any other issues similar to mine but I still attempted all their troubleshooting outlets, despite the fact that I'm running on the fresh install. Curious to see if Riot is aware of such an issue related to patch 7.1.
Again this problem happens randomly and I have noticed absolutely no patterns associated with it. My internet is fine as I have monitored that as I am able to load up other applications with no issue. I've exhausted just about every option I was able to find to pinpoint this problem to no avail.

This error is suggesting that there's a problem or hiccup with your network and losing comms with our servers.  If it was a hard-drive issue, it's likely that it would crash out entirely.  What happens if you're on the legacy client?

-  On the login screen of the open beta updated client, look for the "Launch Legacy Client" text at the bottom.
-  Or create a shortcut directly to the legacy client in your League Installation. Just look for "lol.launcher" 

You might receive an error such as disconnected from pvp.net.  You'll want to troubleshoot this with our [connection issues](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752664-Troubleshooting-Connection-Issues) guide, making sure to go over each step to rule out possibilities.  Let me know if you have any questions!

Legacy client seems to be working fine for now. The hard drive failure was a different reason but nonetheless caused issues everywhere. Any reason why the Beta client is doing this all of a sudden after patch 7.1? I've been using it since it came out and never had this trouble.

Well, there could have been a corruption with an update but that shouldn't necessarily cause network problems.  there could be settings that's causing a block with the updated client, though.  I still recommend going over the connection issues guide to see if that's the case!

Hey guys, after living with this issue for more than 6 months, trying everything in my power to find the answer to this shitty problem, including support tickets, long calls to my ISP and more, I have found that it's probably a problem with the router and its built in firewall. However, there are a lot of ports that needs to be opened for the client to work properly, so the easy solution is to set up your PC as a DMZ on the router.
A DMZ means that the computer will not be protected by the firewalls of the router, which puts your computer at risk, so keep that in mind. 

First, you need to know what is the IP address of your computer. You can find out by opening CMD and typing "ifconfig". It will show you something like "192.168.8.15". That is your computer's IP inside your home network. Do not go to google and type "what is my ip" because that will give you the external IP of your home, and not the internal IP of your computer inside your home network. 

After getting your computer's IP, go into your router's settings and find a setting named DMZ or DMZ server, and put your computer's IP there. 
ENJOY. 

P.S.
Every time you restart your router, your computer gets a different IP address, so you can either set a static IP address to your computer via the network settings in the computer itself, or via DHCP reservation in your router.
